_prev_prog_3.Description:
COVERED PROCESS 2: FERTILIZER BLENDING 



The Warehouse Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other Facility staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



The Facility hires a qualified Contractor (A.K.A. Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor) to blend the APP fertilizer.  The Contractor owns and operates a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR) and is subject to the OSHA PSM rules.  



The Contractor connects the MPR to a railcar containing anhydrous ammonia, a railcar containing super phosphoric acid, and a water supply.  Covered process equipment includes the anhydrous ammonia railcar, nipple adaptors, emergency shutoff valves, transfer hoses, liquid pumps, and the mobile pipe reactor (MPR).  The Contractor transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar and blends the APP fertilizer in accordance with its PSM Operating Procedures.  The IFRC maintains the MPR in accordance with its PSM Maintenance Procedures.

COVERED PROCESS 1: RAILCAR STORAGE (Anhydrous Ammonia) 



The Warehouse Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other Facility staff directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.  



This Facility receives one or more railcars containing anhydrous ammonia from a Carrier and then secures and stores the railcar(s) on the Facility property.   The anhydrous ammonia is used to blend ammonium polyphosphate (APP) fertilizer.  After the anhydrous ammonia is removed from the railcar, the Facility releases the railcar back to the Carrier.  



Facility Process Operators are trained to receive, inspect, and release the railcar(s) in accordance with the Facility PSM/RMP Operating Procedures.  The Facility is not responsible for the maintenance of the railcar(s).  The Facility hires a qualified Contractor to transfer the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar(s) and blend the APP fertilizer (See Covered Process 2).

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC is submitting this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at this Facility.  This electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident, and to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is submitting this as a 5-year update in accordance with the rule.  All accident prevention elements have been reviewed and/or updated.



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of agricultural chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  The covered processes operated at this Facility include:



o    Covered Process 1: Railcar Storage (Anhydrous Ammonia)

o    Covered Process 2: Fertilizer Blending (Ammonium Polyphosphate)



The Facility coordinates delivery of anhydrous ammonia by railcar and hires a Contactor (A.K.A. Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor - IFRC) to transfer and blend anhydrous ammonia with super phosphoric acid and water to make ammonium polyphosphate (APP) fertilizer.  The APP liquid fertilizer is blended in a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR) that is owned and operated by the Contractor.  The APP liquid fertilizer is not subject to the PSM/RMP rules.



The railcar Owner or the Owner Agent is responsible for: loading anhydrous ammonia into railcar(s); coordinating with and releasing custody of railcar(s) to a Carrier; and Mechanical Integrity of railcar(s).  The Facility is responsible for: receiving Custody of the railcar(s); storing the railcar(s); and releasing Custody of railcar(s) to either the Contractor or Carrier.  The Contractor is resp

onsible for: taking custody of the railcar(s) from the Facility; connecting the railcar to the MPR; transferring anhydrous ammonia from the railcar to the MPR; blending the APP liquid fertilizer; and releasing the railcar(s) back to the Facility.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case offsite consequence analyses were completed for both covered processes.  The worst case release scenario is the same for the both covered processes because the largest vessel (i.e. a 34,000-gallon railcar) is common to both covered processes when connected, and the MPR is not capable of storing anhydrous ammonia.  The worst case release scenario assumes that all the content in the largest vessel (i.e. 34,000-gallon railcar) is released.   The release scenario consists of the railcar being punctured on the side at the ground level and the release is modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenarios are different for the two covered processes.  For the Railcar Storage covered process, the alternative consequence analysis assumes that an operator fails to fully close the vapor valve on the railcar.  For the Fertilizer Blending covered process, the alternative consequence analysis assumes that a 3-inch liquid transfer hose is severed during the blending process.  The alternative scenario for the Fertilizer Blending covered process considers active mitigation of the safety equipment (i.e. excess flow valve or back pressure check valve on the railcar; and emergency shutoff valves on the MPR), and operating procedures that the Facility and Contractor implement to safeguard against ammonia releases from transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Warehouse Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Warehouse Manager is assisted by other Facility staff, as directed.  The Warehouse Manager is responsible for ensuring that Facility Staff are properly trained in the implem

entation of the Accident Prevention Program elements.  The Warehouse Manager is responsible for managing the Contractor in accordance with the Facility PSM/RMP Contractor management program.  The Contractor is responsible for training its personnel in the implementation of its OSHA PSM.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility.   The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its LEPC and local fire department.  



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The PSM/RMP implemented by the Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or makes changes to the process. 



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 8 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to this Facility.
